content: This comprehensive guide covers diagnostic procedures for external motorized valves in multi-zone heating systems and cylinders, including testing control circuits.
## PART 1: TYPES AND OPERATION OF MOTORIZED VALVES
- Used to control flow to a single circuit (either ON or OFF)
- Common models: Honeywell V4043H series, Drayton 22mm/28mm zone valves
- Typically 5-wire configuration (Earth, Neutral, Live, plus 2 end switch wires)
- Some 28mm models have a 6th wire (often white) which may be unused
- Controls flow to two separate circuits (heating and hot water)
- Can direct flow to either circuit or both simultaneously
- Typically 5-wire configuration (but wired differently from 2-port valves)
- **S Plan**: Uses multiple 2-port valves (one for heating, one for hot water)
- **Y Plan**: Uses a single 3-port mid-position valve
- **W Plan**: Uses a 3-port diverter valve (different from mid-position)
- **Zoned Systems**: Multiple 2-port valves for different heating zones
- Check for physical damage to valve bodies or actuator heads
- Look for water leaks around valves
- Check wiring for signs of overheating or damage
- Verify correct wiring colors at valve connections
- Set programmer to call for each zone separately
- Listen for motor operation when zone is called for
- Feel pipes for correct temperature changes
- Verify zone responds to thermostat adjustments
- Zones not heating when called for
- All zones heating when only one is called for
- Hot water but no heating (or vice versa)
1. Switch off power to heating system
2. Locate manual lever on valve actuator
- Should feel spring resistance when moving lever
- If no resistance, valve spindle may be seized or broken
- If lever won't stay in MAN position, spring is likely broken
4. With lever in "MAN" position, check flow through valve
- Feel downstream pipe for heat when boiler runs
- Return lever to "AUTO" before restoring power
1. With system powered, call for heat to relevant zone
2. Listen for motor operation (should run briefly when zone called)
3. Feel valve head - should become warm when activated
4. Valve should move from closed to open position
5. After 2-3 minutes, valve head should remain warm if powered
1. Switch off power to heating system
3. Set multimeter to continuity or resistance setting
4. Test between end switch terminals (typically orange and grey wires)
- With valve in closed position: No continuity (open circuit)
- With valve manually opened: Continuity (closed circuit)
5. If no change in continuity when valve position changes, end switch is faulty
1. Switch off power to heating system
3. Disconnect motor wires from control circuit
- For Synchron motors: 2000-2500 Ohms (2.0-2.5 kΩ) is normal
- Open circuit or very high resistance indicates failed motor
- Very low resistance may indicate shorted winding
1. Switch off power to heating system
2. Move manual lever to MAN position and release
- Lever should return to AUTO position when released
- If no spring tension, spring or mechanism may be broken
1. With system powered down, valve defaults to hot water position (port A closed, port B open)
2. When heating called, valve should move to mid-position (both ports open)
3. When only heating required (hot water satisfied), valve moves to heating position (port A open, port B closed)
1. Switch off power to heating system
- Grey: Used to drive valve to heating-only position
3. With system powered for different modes, check:
- Hot water only: Grey and white wires de-energized
- Heating and hot water: White wire energized (~230V AC), grey de-energized
- Heating only: Both white and grey wires energized (~230V AC)
1. Switch off power to heating system
2. Remove valve actuator (powerhead) from valve body
3. Check if valve spindle moves freely manually
4. If spindle is stuck, check for:
- Listen for relay clicks when changing modes
- Switch off power to heating system
- Restore power and measure at programmer terminals:
- Hot water ON: 230V AC at hot water output terminal
- Heating ON: 230V AC at heating output terminal
- Should hear click as contacts close
- With multimeter, check for continuity when calling for heat
- Verify voltage passes through when contacts closed
- If hot water is below set temperature, should have continuity
- As cylinder heats up, continuity should break at set point
- Check sensor is securely attached to cylinder
- Check for burned or loose terminals
- Trace wires from programmer to valves
- Check for short circuits between terminals
- Verify voltage transmission through wiring center
- Listen for audible clicking when zones are switched
- Check for voltage at relay outputs when activated
## PART 5: COMMON FAULT SCENARIOS AND SOLUTIONS
1. Faulty room thermostat or cylinder thermostat
2. Damaged or stuck microswitch inside valve
3. Incorrect wiring at valve or controller
4. Valve jammed, preventing end position being reached
1. Disconnect thermostat wires - if motor stops, thermostat or wiring is faulty
2. Check for debris or damage in valve mechanism
3. Verify correct wiring configuration for valve type
4. Test motor resistance when disconnected from circuit
4. Broken linkage between motor and valve
1. Check for 230V AC at motor terminals when zone called
3. Try manual operation to check for seized mechanism
1. Trace pipes to confirm correct valve installation
### Multiple Zones Heating When Only One Called
3. Wiring fault creating feedback between zones
1. Check each valve manually - should close when not called
2. Test for voltage feedback between zones
3. Isolate zones by disconnecting at controller
### No Boiler Firing When Zones Called
2. Break in the boiler enable circuit
3. Faulty wiring from valve to boiler
1. Check for 230V at boiler live terminal when zone active
2. Test end switch continuity when valve open
3. Verify complete circuit from controller through valve to boiler
4. Temporarily bypass valve switch to test boiler directly
Creating a systematic approach to eliminate variables:
- Wire temporary live feed directly to valve
- Verifies valve operation independent of control system
2. **Valve End Switch Testing with Test Lamp**
- Connect test lamp across end switch terminals
- Lamp should illuminate when valve reaches open position
- Test heating and hot water circuits independently
- Isolate each zone valve to pinpoint problematic component
### Using Logic Probes for Control Circuits
For advanced diagnostics with electronic controls:
1. Connect logic probe to control circuit
4. Identify irregular signals or missing pulses
1. Turn off power to heating system
3. Pull actuator straight up from valve body
5. Align new actuator with valve body
7. Reconnect wiring (note wire colors and positions)
1. Turn off power to heating system
2. Isolate and drain affected heating circuit
- Verify flow direction arrow matches system flow
- Ensure correct orientation of ports (for 3-port valves)
- Make pipe connections (use appropriate jointing compound)
- Connect wiring according to manufacturer's diagram
5. Refill system and test for leaks
- Look for signs of water leakage
- Manually exercise each valve twice yearly
- Verify smooth operation of manual lever
- Check for unusual noises during operation
- High pressure can damage valve seals
- Use appropriate inhibitor to prevent scale
- Consider magnetic filter to protect valves from debris
- Consider surge protection for control circuits
- White: (28mm models only) Often not used
| Synchron Motor | 2000-2500 Ω | Measured across motor terminals |
| Valve Motor Live | Zone called | 230V AC |
| Valve Motor Live | Zone satisfied | 0V AC |
| End Switch Output | Valve open | 230V AC |
| End Switch Output | Valve closed | 0V AC |
| 3-Port Grey Wire | Heating only (no HW) | 230V AC |
